FacilityName: E. R. Carpenter L.P. - Powell Plant

_prev_prog_3.Description: The same prevention program information applies to the six polyol units which are represented by the four covered polyol production processes and to the methyl formate system.  The polyol units and the methyl formate system are covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule, and the prevention program that is currently in place is designed to comply with that rule.  Process hazard analyses have been conducted for all of the polyol units and the methyl formate system.  The polyol processes and the methyl formate system utilize interlocks, emergency air and cooling water supplies, backup power systems, backup pumps, rupture discs and relief valves, excess flow control devices, quench systems, purge systems and hydrocarbon detectors, as appropriate, to prevent or minimize accidental releases.  The chemical blending unit which is also included in the Risk Management Plan is covered by Program 1 in the Risk Management Program Rule, and its prevention program is not addressed here.

_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Updated procedures and modified operation of oxide line nitrogen bubble system.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ethylene oxide and propylene oxide piping at P-3 Reactor.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

E. R. Carpenter, L.P. is totally committed to the safe operation of its Roger W. Powell chemical production facility.  Engineering safeguards and safety factors have been incorporated throughout the processes employed and have been reviewed in detail as part of the Process Safety Management program.  Additionally, senior management has and will continue to ensure that resources are available for the materials, equipment, and training required for safe operation of the facility.  Facility safety is a team goal which is successfully achieved through the combined efforts of each individual onsite and the commitment of senior management.

Facility and Regulated Substances Handled:

The E. R. Carpenter, L.P., Roger W. Powell Plant, located at 11002 Choate Rd., Pasadena, Texas, manufactures polyether polyols and prepares blends of polyether polyols with various other materials for internal company use and for external sale.  The first polyether polyol production unit at the facility, the P-1 Unit, was started up in 1973, and since that time five additional polyether polyol production units, the P-2, P-3, P-4, P-5 and P-6 Units and a blending facility have been added.  In addition, the facility is currently adding the capability to repackage methyl formate for distribution to other Carpenter sites.  Approximately 100 Carpenter personnel work at the facility on a full-time basis.

The polyether polyol production units are designed to produce batch quantities of various low vapor pressure polyether polyols.  Production of a typical polyether polyol involves the reaction of ethylene oxide and/or propylene oxide with a starter material such as glycerine.  Ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, formaldehyde and ethylenediamine are the regulated substances in these units.   

Ethylene oxide is supplied to the plant by railcar to four closed, nitrogen-padded and externally-refrigerated pressure vessels a

nd is fed via pumps to the reactors at the facility.  Propylene oxide is supplied via pipeline and/or railcar and/or tank truck to four closed, nitrogen-padded pressure vessels and is fed via pump or directly via pipeline to the reactors at the facility.  Formaldehyde is received as a water solution via tank trucks, and is stored in a nitrogen-padded tank with a conservation vent.  It is fed via pump from the storage tank to one of the reactors at the facility.  Ethylenediamine is received via tank truck and is transferred directly from the tank truck to two of the reactors at the facility.

For the purposes of the Risk Management Plan, the six polyol production units have been grouped into four processes.  The P-1 and P-2 polyol production units have been grouped together into one process as they share the same ethylene oxide and propylene oxide storage vessels.  The P-3 and P-6 polyol production units have also been grouped together into one process as they share the same ethylene oxide and propylene oxide storage vessels.  The P-4 and P-5  polyol production processes each have their own ethylene oxide and propylene oxide storage vessels and are considered separate processes.

The chemical blending unit is designed to produce batch quantities of various blended polyol and isocyanate products, and to drum polyols and isocyanates.  Production of a typical chemical blending product involves the mixing of either a polyol or an isocyanate with small amounts of other raw materials to produce one part of a two-part polyurethane foam producing system.  Toluene diisocyanate is the regulated substance in this unit.

The toluene diisocyanate that is used at the blending facility is received in bulk via tank truck and is stored in a nitrogen-padded pressure vessel.  It is fed via pump to a nitrogen padded mix tank where it is mixed with a polyol and other raw materials to produce a finished product.  

For the purposes of the Risk Management Plan, the chemical blending unit i

s considered a separate process from the polyol production processes.  The toluene diisocyanate storage and mix system is independent of the polyol production processes.

As mentioned above, the capability to repackage methyl formate for shipment to other Carpenter sites is being added.  The methyl formate will be received in iso containers and transferred to a railcar for temporary storage.  Methyl formate in the railcar will be transferred to portable pressure tanks for shipment offsite.  Methyl formate is a regulated substance, and the methyl formate repackaging operation is considered an independent process for the purposes of the Risk Management Plan.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

All of our polyol production processes use ethylene oxide and propylene oxide as major raw materials.  In addition, the P-1 and P-3 polyol production units use ethylenediamine as a raw material, and the P-3 polyol production unit uses formaldehyde as a raw material.  Ethylene oxide, propylene oxide and formaldehyde are covered by OSHAA?s Process Safety Management regulations, as well as the Risk Management Program rule, and as such, their use is subject to significant safe management review.  Ethylenediamine is not covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management regulations, but it is subjected to the same reviews as the other three chemicals.  Prevention measures in place include extensive process controls (e.g., safety interlocks, pressure monitoring systems, etc.), mitigation systems (i.e. dry and wet sprinklers/deluge systems) and detection systems (i.e., process area hydrocarbon detection systems).  We have procedures such as our Preventive Maintenance Program, Lockout/Tagout Procedure, Incident Investigation Procedure and Process Change Authorization Procedure in place to minimize the possibility of an incident. We also have an extensive Chemical Operator Training program in place to ensure that operations personnel know ho

w to operate the processes in a safe manner, and we have performed Process Hazard Analyses to evaluate our systems.

Our chemical blending process which uses toluene diisocyanate as a primary raw material is not covered by OSHAA?s Process Safety Management regulations and is not subject to the Risk Management Program prevention requirements.   However, the operation does have standard operating procedures designed to minimize the potential for releases and is covered by the Lockout/Tagout and Incident Investigation procedures at the facility. 

The methyl formate which will be handled in the repackaging process that is being added is covered by OSHA's Process Safety Management regulations as well as the Risk Management Program rule, and it will be managed just like ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, formaldehyde and ethylenediamine are currently managed.  Prevention measures will include an automatic transfer pump shutoff, as well as our Preventive Maintenance Program, Lockout/Tagout Procedure, Incident Investigation Procedure and Process Change Authorization Procedure.  In addition, Process Hazard Analyses will be conducted periodically, and operations personnel will receive training on the system and will be certified on its operation before they are allowed to conduct repackaging operations.

Five-Year Accident History:

There have been no incidents with off-site or significant on-site impacts during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program:

Our Emergency Response Program consists of the following elements:  emergency pre-planning including coordination with local emergency response organizations; internal plant emergency alarm procedures; call out and internal and external notification procedures; and response procedures for chemical releases and other emergencies.  Training is provided annually on the management of emergencies involving hazardous materials and fire response, and plant drills are conducted regularly.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

N
o significant changes are planned at this time.
